2022–23 Figure Skating Season

The 2022–23 figure skating season began on July 1, 2022, and will end on June 30, 2023. During this season, elite figure skaters will compete on the international senior level in the men's singles, women's singles, pairs, and ice dance disciplines. This season's competitions will include the 2022-23 ISU Grand Prix series, the 2022-23 ISU Challenger Series, and the 2023 World Figure Skating Championships.

# Season Notes

## Age Eligibility

To be eligible to compete at the senior level, skaters must be at least 16 years old by July 1, 2022, in the men's singles, women's singles, and pairs disciplines, and at least 15 years old by July 1, 2022, in the ice dance discipline.

## Death of Dmytro Sharpar

Ukrainian figure skater Dmytro Sharpar passed away on June 13, 2022, at the age of 32. Sharpar was a two-time Ukrainian national champion and competed at the 2018 Winter Olympics.

# Changes

## Partnership Changes

Several partnership changes occurred during the off-season. Russian pair skaters Anastasia Mishina and Aleksandr Galliamov announced their split, with Mishina teaming up with new partner Dmitry Epstein. Canadian ice dancers Piper Gilles and Paul Poirier announced their split, with Gilles teaming up with new partner Donovan Carrillo.

## Retirements

Several skaters announced their retirement from competitive figure skating during the off-season. Russian figure skater Alina Zagitova, the 2018 Olympic champion, announced her retirement in December 2022. Canadian pair skaters Kirsten Moore-Towers and Michael Marinaro announced their retirement in June 2022.

## Coaching Changes

Several skaters changed coaches during the off-season. Japanese figure skater Yuma Kagiyama switched coaches to Alexei Urmanov. American figure skater Alysa Liu switched coaches to Massimo Scali.

## Nationality Changes

Several skaters changed their nationality during the off-season. Russian figure skater Elizaveta Tuktamysheva switched to competing for Azerbaijan. Canadian ice dancer Laurence Fournier Beaudry switched to competing for Canada, having previously competed for France.

Boycott of Russia and Belarus

The boycott of Russia and Belarus refers to the international sanctions and boycotts imposed on Russia and Belarus in response to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. The boycotts have been implemented by various countries, companies, and organizations, and have had significant impacts on the economies and international relations of both Russia and Belarus.

# Overview

The boycotts were initiated in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24, 2022. The invasion was widely condemned by the international community, and led to a series of economic sanctions and boycotts being imposed on Russia and Belarus. The boycotts have been implemented by various countries, including the United States, the European Union, and the United Kingdom, as well as by individual companies and organizations.

The boycotts have had significant impacts on the economies of Russia and Belarus. The Russian economy has been particularly hard hit, with the value of the ruble falling sharply and inflation rising. The Belarusian economy has also been affected, although to a lesser extent. The boycotts have also had significant impacts on international relations, with Russia and Belarus becoming increasingly isolated from the rest of the world.

Olivia Newton-John
================

Olivia Newton-John is a British-Australian singer, actress, and activist who has been active in the entertainment industry since the late 1960s. With a career spanning over five decades, she has established herself as one of the most successful and beloved artists of all time. Newton-John's music and film career has been marked by numerous chart-topping hits, iconic movie roles, and a commitment to philanthropy and advocacy.

Early Life and Family
--------------------

Olivia Newton-John was born on September 26, 1948, in Cambridge, England, to Brinley Newton-John and Irene Born. Her father was a Welsh-born professor of German, and her mother was an Australian-born daughter of a Nobel Prize-winning mathematician. Newton-John has two siblings, Hugh and Rona, and the family moved to Melbourne, Australia, when she was six years old. She developed an early interest in music and began taking singing lessons at the age of nine.

Career
-------

### Career Beginnings

Newton-John's music career began in the late 1960s, when she formed a girl group called Sol Four with her friends. The group performed on local television shows and at parties, but eventually disbanded. In 1966, Newton-John won a talent contest on a local television show, which led to her being signed by Decca Records. She released her debut single, "Till You Say You'll Be Mine," in 1966, but it failed to chart.

### 1971–1974: Early Success

Newton-John's breakthrough came in 1971, when she released her debut album, "If Not for You," which was produced by John Farrar. The album was a moderate success in Australia, but it was her 1971 single "If Not for You" that brought her international attention. The song was a cover of a Bob Dylan track and became a hit in the United States, reaching the top 10 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. Newton-John's subsequent albums, "Olivia" (1972) and "Let Me Be There" (1973), solidified her position as a rising star in the music industry.

### 1975–1977: Have You Never Been Mellow, Clearly Love, and Continued Success

In 1975, Newton-John released the album "Have You Never Been Mellow," which spawned the hit singles "Have You Never Been Mellow" and "Please Mr. Please." The album was a huge commercial success, reaching number one on the US Billboard 200 chart and earning Newton-John her first Grammy Award. Her subsequent albums, "Clearly Love" (1975) and "Come On Over" (1976), continued her string of hits, with songs like "Let It Shine" and "Come On Over."

### 1978–1979: Grease and Totally Hot

Newton-John's biggest break came in 1978, when she was cast as Sandy Olsson in the musical film "Grease," opposite John Travolta. The film was a massive success, and Newton-John's performance earned her a Golden Globe nomination. The soundtrack to the film, which featured Newton-John's hit singles "You're the One That I Want" and "Hopelessly Devoted to You," became one of the best-selling soundtracks of all time. Newton-John's subsequent album, "Totally Hot" (1978), was a commercial success, but received mixed reviews from critics.

#### Lawsuit against MCA Records

In 1979, Newton-John sued MCA Records, claiming that the label had not paid her royalties on time. The lawsuit was eventually settled out of court, but it led to a public feud between Newton-John and the label.

### 1980–1988: Physical, Soul Kiss, and The Rumour

Newton-John's next album, "Physical" (1981), was a huge commercial success, spawning the hit singles "Physical" and "Make a Move on Me." The album was certified multi-platinum and became one of the best-selling albums of the 1980s. Newton-John's subsequent albums, "Soul Kiss" (1985) and "The Rumour" (1988), were less successful, but still featured hit singles like "Soul Kiss" and "The Rumour."

### 1989–1998: Motherhood, Cancer, and Advocacy

In 1989, Newton-John gave birth to her only child, Chloe Lattanzi. She took a break from her music career to focus on motherhood, but continued to perform and record music. In 1992, Newton-John was diagnosed with breast cancer, which led to her becoming a prominent advocate for cancer research and awareness. She underwent treatment and made a full recovery, but continued to be open about her experiences with cancer.

### 1998–2012: Later Releases

Newton-John's music career continued with the release of the album "Back with a Heart" (1998), which featured the hit single "I Honestly Love You." She released several more albums, including "One Woman's Live Journey" (2000) and "Indigo: Women of Song" (2004), which featured covers of songs by female artists.

### 2012–2022: Vegas Residency and Final Releases

In 2012, Newton-John began a residency at the Flamingo Las Vegas, which ran for several years. She released the album "A Celebration in Song" (2012), which featured duets with other artists, and "LIV ON" (2016), which featured songs about overcoming adversity. Newton-John's final studio album, "Unforgettable" (2020), was a collection of cover songs.

In the Media
-------------

Newton-John has been featured in numerous films and television shows, including "Grease," "Xanadu," "Two of a Kind," and "Glee." She has also appeared on various reality TV shows, including "Dancing with the Stars" and "The Apprentice."

Musical Legacy
----------------

Newton-John's music career has had a lasting impact on the industry. She has been named one of the best-selling music artists of all time, with over 100 million records sold worldwide. Her music has been featured in numerous films, television shows, and commercials, and she has been cited as an influence by numerous other artists.

Personal Life
-------------

### Relationships

Newton-John has been married twice, first to Bruce Welch, a British musician, from 1970 to 1975. She married John Easterling, an American businessman, in 2008.

### Residences and Citizenship

Newton-John has lived in various locations throughout her life, including Australia, the United States, and the United Kingdom. She holds dual citizenship of Australia and the United Kingdom.

Illness and Death

Newton-John died on August 8, 2022, at the age of 73, after a long battle with breast cancer. Her death was met with an outpouring of tributes from fans and fellow artists around the world.

Awards and Honours

December 2022 Twitter Suspensions

The December 2022 Twitter suspensions refer to a series of account suspensions that took place on the social media platform Twitter in December 2022. The suspensions targeted various accounts, including those of journalists, flight-tracking services, and other users. The incident drew significant attention and raised concerns about Twitter's moderation policies and the role of its owner, Elon Musk.

#Background

In October 2022, Elon Musk acquired Twitter for approximately $44 billion. Following the acquisition, Musk announced plans to reform Twitter's moderation policies, which he believed were too restrictive. He also stated his intention to promote free speech on the platform. However, the changes implemented by Musk were met with criticism from various groups, including journalists, activists, and politicians.

#Account suspensions

##Twitter policy changes

In early December 2022, Twitter updated its policies to prohibit the sharing of "live location information" and "links to third-party URL(s) of travel routes in real-time." The changes were seen as an attempt to restrict the sharing of information about the location of private jets, including those owned by Musk.

##Suspension of flight-tracking accounts

On December 14, 2022, Twitter suspended several accounts that tracked the location of private jets, including those owned by Musk. The accounts, which used publicly available data to track the flights, were accused of violating Twitter's new policies. The suspensions were seen as an attempt to conceal information about Musk's private jet movements.

##Suspension of journalist accounts

On December 15, 2022, Twitter suspended the accounts of several journalists who had covered Musk and Twitter. The journalists, who worked for various news organizations, were accused of violating Twitter's policies. However, many saw the suspensions as an attempt to silence critics of Musk and Twitter.

##Explanation from Twitter and Musk

Twitter and Musk defended the suspensions, stating that the accounts had violated the platform's policies. Musk claimed that the journalists had engaged in "doxxing" – the act of publishing private information about individuals without their consent. However, many of the suspended journalists denied the allegations, stating that they had only shared publicly available information.

#Reinstatement of some accounts

On December 16, 2022, Twitter reinstated the accounts of several journalists who had been suspended. The reinstatement came after widespread criticism of the suspensions, including from various news organizations and human rights groups. However, some accounts remained suspended, and the incident raised concerns about the consistency and fairness of Twitter's moderation policies.

#Responses

##Suspended journalists

The journalists who were suspended by Twitter expressed outrage and disappointment at the decision. Many saw the suspensions as an attempt to silence critics of Musk and Twitter, and to conceal information about Musk's private jet movements. The journalists also expressed concern about the impact of the suspensions on press freedom and the ability of journalists to report on important issues.

##Other commentators

Other commentators, including academics, activists, and politicians, also criticized the suspensions. Many saw the incident as a sign of the dangers of unchecked corporate power and the importance of protecting freedom of speech and the press. Others expressed concern about the potential consequences of the suspensions for Twitter's users and for the broader public discourse.

#See also

* Twitter suspensions
* Elon Musk
* Twitter moderation policies
* Press freedom
* Freedom of speech

article:
Visarion Puiu

Visarion Puiu (1879-1964) was a Romanian Orthodox cleric, theologian, and writer who served as the Metropolitan of Bukovina, Exarch of Transnistria, and Bishop of the Romanian Orthodox Diocese of Western Europe. His life and career were marked by significant events, including his involvement in the Romanian Orthodox Church's relations with the Soviet Union, his exile in Nazi Germany and Italy, and his subsequent trial for war crimes.

#Early life and monastic career

Visarion Puiu was born on January 16, 1879, in Câmpulung Moldovenesc, a town in the Austro-Hungarian Empire (now in Romania). He came from a family of modest means, with his father working as a merchant and his mother as a homemaker. Puiu's early education took place at the local primary school, where he demonstrated a keen interest in theology and literature.

In 1895, Puiu entered the Monastery of Neamț, a prominent Orthodox monastery in Moldavia, where he began his monastic career. He studied theology at the monastery's seminary and was tonsured as a monk in 1901. Puiu's ascetic life and devotion to his studies earned him the respect of his superiors, who appointed him as a teacher at the monastery's seminary.

#Metropolitan of Bukovina

In 1921, Puiu was elected as the Metropolitan of Bukovina, a province in northeastern Romania. As metropolitan, Puiu played a crucial role in promoting the Romanian Orthodox Church's interests in the region. He worked tirelessly to establish new parishes, schools, and social institutions, which helped to strengthen the Church's presence in Bukovina.

During his tenure as metropolitan, Puiu also became involved in the Church's relations with the Soviet Union. In 1924, he participated in a delegation of Romanian Orthodox clergy who visited Moscow to negotiate with Soviet authorities about the status of the Orthodox Church in the Soviet Union. Puiu's involvement in these negotiations helped to establish him as a key figure in the Church's relations with the Soviet Union.

#Exarch of Transnistria

In 1938, Puiu was appointed as the Exarch of Transnistria, a region in eastern Romania that was annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. As exarch, Puiu was responsible for overseeing the Orthodox Church's activities in the region. However, his tenure was cut short when the Soviet Union annexed Transnistria in 1940.

##Voyage to Croatia and exile in Nazi Germany

Following the annexation of Transnistria, Puiu fled to Croatia, where he sought refuge with the Croatian Orthodox Church. However, he soon found himself in danger due to his vocal criticism of the Croatian fascist regime. In 1941, Puiu traveled to Nazi Germany, where he was received by the German Orthodox Church. He spent the remainder of World War II in exile in Germany, where he continued to write and engage in theological debates.

##Exile in Italy and trial for war crimes

In 1945, Puiu traveled to Italy, where he was arrested by Allied authorities on suspicion of war crimes. Puiu was accused of collaborating with the Nazi regime and of promoting anti-Semitic views. He was put on trial in 1947, but was ultimately acquitted due to lack of evidence.

##Bishop of the Romanian Orthodox Diocese of Western Europe

In 1950, Puiu was appointed as the Bishop of the Romanian Orthodox Diocese of Western Europe, a position that allowed him to continue his ministry among Romanian Orthodox communities in Western Europe. Puiu played an important role in promoting the interests of the Romanian Orthodox Church in Western Europe, and worked tirelessly to establish new parishes and institutions.

##Final years and death

Puiu spent his final years in exile in Western Europe, where he continued to write and engage in theological debates. He died on August 10, 1964, in Paris, France, at the age of 85. Puiu's legacy as a theologian and writer was cemented in the years following his death, as his works were widely published and studied.

#Posthumous evaluation

The Albury & District Football League was formed in 1920, with five founding clubs: Albury, East Albury, North Albury, South Albury, and West Albury. article:
History of Taiwan

Taiwan, officially known as the Republic of China (ROC), has a rich and complex history that spans thousands of years. From the indigenous peoples who first inhabited the island to the Dutch and Spanish colonizers, the Chinese settlers, and the Japanese and American influences, Taiwan's history has been shaped by a diverse array of cultures and empires. This article provides an overview of the major periods in Taiwanese history, from prehistory to the present day.

# Prehistory

The island of Taiwan has been inhabited by indigenous peoples for thousands of years. Archaeological evidence suggests that the first inhabitants of Taiwan were the Austronesian peoples, who migrated to the island from mainland Asia around 6,000 years ago. These early settlers developed a thriving culture, with their own languages, customs, and traditions. The Austronesian peoples were skilled farmers, hunters, and gatherers, and they lived in small villages and tribes.

# Chinese contact and settlement

The first recorded contact between Taiwan and China dates back to the 7th century, when Chinese fishermen and traders began to visit the island. However, it was not until the 17th century that Chinese settlement of Taiwan began in earnest. In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a trading post on the island, and Chinese immigrants began to arrive in large numbers. These early Chinese settlers were primarily from the provinces of Fujian and Guangdong, and they brought with them their own languages, customs, and traditions.

# Dutch and Spanish colonies (1624–1668)

## Contact and establishment

In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a trading post on the island of Taiwan, which they named Fort Zeelandia. The Dutch were attracted to Taiwan by its strategic location and its natural resources, including sugar, rice, and deerskins. The Dutch trading post was established at Anping, on the southwestern coast of Taiwan, and it quickly became a major center of trade and commerce.

## Piracy

However, the Dutch presence in Taiwan was not without its challenges. Pirates and privateers were a major problem, and the Dutch had to contend with frequent attacks on their shipping and their settlements. In 1626, the Dutch established a second trading post at Keelung, on the northeastern coast of Taiwan, in an effort to expand their control over the island.

## Japanese trade

In the 1630s, the Dutch began to trade with Japan, which had recently been opened to European trade. The Dutch traded with the Japanese for silver, copper, and other valuable commodities, and they used Taiwan as a base for their trade with Japan.

## Spanish Formosa

In 1626, the Spanish established their own colony on Taiwan, which they named Spanish Formosa. The Spanish colony was established at Keelung, on the northeastern coast of Taiwan, and it was intended to serve as a base for Spanish trade and missionary activity in the region.

## Dutch colonization

In the 1640s, the Dutch began to expand their control over Taiwan, and they established a number of new settlements and trading posts on the island. The Dutch colonization of Taiwan was accompanied by the forced relocation of indigenous peoples and the introduction of European diseases, which had a devastating impact on the native population.

## Chinese settlers

During the Dutch period, Chinese settlers continued to arrive on Taiwan, and they established their own communities and villages. The Chinese settlers were primarily from the provinces of Fujian and Guangdong, and they brought with them their own languages, customs, and traditions.

## End of Dutch rule

In 1662, the Dutch were driven out of Taiwan by the Chinese pirate-king Koxinga, who established the Kingdom of Tungning on the island. The Dutch period in Taiwan had lasted for 38 years, and it had a lasting impact on the island's history and culture.

# Kingdom of Tungning (1661–1683)

## Conquest

In 1661, the Chinese pirate-king Koxinga, also known as Zheng Chenggong, conquered Taiwan and drove out the Dutch. Koxinga was a Ming loyalist who had fled to Taiwan after the fall of the Ming dynasty to the Qing in 1644. He established the Kingdom of Tungning on Taiwan, which was intended to serve as a base for his efforts to restore the Ming dynasty.

## Retreat to Taiwan

Koxinga's conquest of Taiwan was motivated by his desire to establish a safe haven for his followers and to launch a campaign to retake the mainland from the Qing. However, his efforts were ultimately unsuccessful, and he was forced to retreat to Taiwan, where he died in 1662.

## Sinicization

During the Kingdom of Tungning period, Taiwan underwent a process of sinicization, as Chinese culture and traditions were introduced to the island. The Chinese settlers established their own communities and villages, and they brought with them their own languages, customs, and traditions.

## Shi Lang

In 1683, the Qing general Shi Lang conquered Taiwan and incorporated it into the Qing empire. Shi Lang was a Ming loyalist who had defected to the Qing and had been tasked with conquering Taiwan. He established a new government on the island, which was intended to serve as a base for Qing rule in the region.

## End of Zheng rule

The Kingdom of Tungning period came to an end in 1683, when the Qing general Shi Lang conquered Taiwan and incorporated it into the Qing empire. The Zheng family, who had ruled Taiwan since 1662, were forced to flee, and the island was brought under Qing control.

# Qing dynasty (1683–1895)

## Annexation

In 1683, the Qing dynasty annexed Taiwan, and the island was incorporated into the Qing empire. The Qing government established a new administrative system on the island, which was intended to serve as a base for Qing rule in the region.

## Taiwan administration

During the Qing period, Taiwan was administered as a part of the Fujian province. The Qing government established a number of new administrative offices on the island, including the Taiwan Prefecture, which was responsible for governing the island.

## Settler expansion (1684–1795)

During the Qing period, Chinese settlement of Taiwan continued to expand, as new immigrants arrived on the island. The Chinese settlers established their own communities and villages, and they brought with them their own languages, customs, and traditions.

## Administrative expansion (1796–1874)

In the 19th century, the Qing government expanded its administrative control over Taiwan, establishing new offices and institutions on the island. The Qing government also introduced new policies and reforms, intended to modernize and strengthen its rule over the island.

## Expansion in reaction to crises (1875–1895)

In the late 19th century, the Qing government faced a number of crises, including the Opium Wars and the Taiping Rebellion. In response to these crises, the Qing government expanded its control over Taiwan, establishing new offices and institutions on the island.

## Rebellions

During the Qing period, Taiwan experienced a number of rebellions and uprisings, as indigenous peoples and Chinese settlers resisted Qing rule. The most notable rebellion was the Taiping Rebellion, which began in 1850 and lasted for 14 years.

## Invasions

Taiwan was also subject to a number of invasions and attacks during the Qing period, including the French invasion of 1884 and the Japanese invasion of 1895.

## End of Qing rule

The Qing period in Taiwan came to an end in 1895, when the island was ceded to Japan following the First Sino-Japanese War. The Qing government had ruled Taiwan for 212 years, and its legacy continues to shape the island's history and culture to this day.

# Japanese Empire (1895–1945)

## Armed resistance

Following the Japanese occupation of Taiwan, there was a period of armed resistance, as Taiwanese rebels fought against Japanese rule. The most notable rebellion was the Xilai An Incident, which began in 1915 and lasted for several years.

## Non-violent resistance

In addition to armed resistance, there was also a non-violent resistance movement in Taiwan, as Taiwanese activists and intellectuals sought to promote reform and independence through peaceful means.

## Assimilation movement

During the Japanese period, there was a significant assimilation movement, as Taiwanese people were encouraged to adopt Japanese language, customs, and traditions. The Japanese government also introduced a number of policies and reforms, intended to promote assimilation and integration.

## Education

The Japanese government introduced a new education system in Taiwan, which was intended to promote Japanese language and culture. Taiwanese students were required to study Japanese, and many were sent to Japan for further education.

## Japanization

The Japanese government also introduced a number of policies and reforms, intended to promote Japanization and assimilation. Taiwanese people were encouraged to adopt Japanese names, and many were forced to abandon their traditional customs and practices.

## Aboriginal policies

The Japanese government also introduced a number of policies and reforms, intended to address the needs of Taiwan's indigenous peoples. However, these policies were often paternalistic and assimilationist, and they had a negative impact on indigenous communities.

## Japanese colonists

During the Japanese period, there was a significant influx of Japanese colonists, who came to Taiwan to work and settle. The Japanese colonists played a significant role in shaping Taiwan's economy and society, and many remained on the island after the end of Japanese rule.

## Industrialization

The Japanese government introduced a number of policies and reforms, intended to promote industrialization and modernization in Taiwan. The island became a major center of industry and trade, and its economy flourished during the Japanese period.

## World War II

During World War II, Taiwan played a significant role in the Japanese war effort, and the island was subject to Allied bombing and attack. The war had a devastating impact on Taiwan's economy and society, and many Taiwanese people suffered greatly during this period.

## End of Japanese rule

The Japanese period in Taiwan came to an end in 1945, when the island was occupied by the Allied powers following Japan's defeat in World War II. The Japanese government had ruled Taiwan for 50 years, and its legacy continues to shape the island's history and culture to this day.

# Republic of China (1945–present)

## Taiwan under martial law

Following the end of Japanese rule, Taiwan was occupied by the Nationalist government of the Republic of China, which had retreated to the island after its defeat in the Chinese Civil War. The Nationalist government imposed martial law on Taiwan, which lasted for 38 years.

## Economic development

During the Nationalist period, Taiwan experienced rapid economic development, as the government introduced a number of policies and reforms intended to promote economic growth and modernization. The island became a major center of industry and trade, and its economy flourished during this period.

## Democratic reforms

In the 1980s, Taiwan began to undergo a process of democratic reform, as the government introduced a number of policies and reforms intended to promote democracy and human rights. The island held its first free elections in 1996, and it has since become a thriving democracy.

## Democratic period

Today, Taiwan is a thriving democracy, with a strong economy and a vibrant culture. The island continues to face challenges, including its complex relationship with China and its ongoing efforts to promote democracy and human rights. However, Taiwan remains a beacon of hope and freedom in East Asia, and its people continue to work towards a brighter future.

article:
Effects of Climate Change

Climate change refers to the long-term warming of the planet, which is primarily caused by the increasing levels of greenhouse gases in the Earth's atmosphere. These gases, such as carbon dioxide and methane, trap heat from the sun, leading to a rise in global temperatures. The effects of climate change are widespread and varied, impacting not only the environment but also human societies and economies.

# Changes in Temperature

One of the most direct effects of climate change is the increase in global temperatures. The average global temperature has risen by about 1°C since the late 19th century, and the 20 warmest years on record have all occurred since 1981. This warming is not uniform, with some regions experiencing more rapid warming than others. The Arctic, for example, is warming at a rate twice as fast as the global average.

# Weather

Climate change is also altering weather patterns around the world. This includes changes in precipitation, temperature extremes, and weather events such as heatwaves, droughts, and storms.

## Heat Waves and Temperature Extremes

Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and prolonged, with some regions experiencing temperatures that are 3-4°C higher than the average high temperature. This can have severe impacts on human health, particularly for vulnerable populations such as the elderly and young children. Temperature extremes are also becoming more common, with some areas experiencing temperatures that are 5-6°C higher than the average high temperature.

## Rain

Changes in precipitation patterns are also occurring, with some regions experiencing more frequent and intense rainfall events. This can lead to flooding, landslides, and other hazards. In contrast, other regions are experiencing more frequent and prolonged droughts, which can have severe impacts on agriculture and water resources.

## Extreme Storms

Climate change is also leading to more frequent and intense extreme weather events, such as hurricanes, typhoons, and cyclones. These storms can cause catastrophic damage to infrastructure, homes, and the environment, and can also lead to loss of life.

# Land

Climate change is having significant impacts on land, including changes in sea levels, more frequent natural disasters, and altered ecosystems.

## Floods

Rising sea levels and more frequent extreme weather events are leading to more frequent and severe flooding. This can have devastating impacts on communities, particularly in low-lying coastal areas.

## Droughts

Droughts are becoming more frequent and prolonged, with some regions experiencing severe water shortages. This can have significant impacts on agriculture, industry, and human consumption.

## Wildfires

Climate change is also leading to more frequent and severe wildfires, particularly in regions with rising temperatures and changing precipitation patterns. These fires can have devastating impacts on ecosystems, human health, and the economy.

# Oceans

Climate change is having significant impacts on the world's oceans, including rising sea levels, ocean acidification, and changes in marine ecosystems.

## Sea Level Rise

Rising sea levels are one of the most significant impacts of climate change, with the global sea level rising by about 15-20 cm since 1900. This can lead to more frequent and severe coastal erosion, flooding, and saltwater intrusion into freshwater sources.

# Ice and Snow

Climate change is also having significant impacts on ice and snow, including the decline of glaciers, ice sheets, and sea ice.

## Glaciers Decline

Glaciers around the world are retreating at an unprecedented rate, with some glaciers losing up to 90% of their mass in recent decades. This can have significant impacts on sea levels, water resources, and ecosystems.

## Ice Sheets Decline

The world's two largest ice sheets, in Greenland and Antarctica, are also declining at an unprecedented rate. This can have significant impacts on sea levels, with some estimates suggesting that the Greenland ice sheet alone could raise sea levels by up to 7 meters.

## Sea Ice Decline

The extent and thickness of sea ice in the Arctic are declining at an unprecedented rate, with some estimates suggesting that the Arctic could be ice-free in the summer by the 2040s. This can have significant impacts on ecosystems, including the loss of habitat for polar bears and other species.

## Permafrost Thawing

Permafrost, or frozen ground, is thawing at an unprecedented rate, with some estimates suggesting that up to 70% of the world's permafrost could thaw by 2100. This can have significant impacts on ecosystems, including the release of methane and other greenhouse gases.

# Wildlife and Nature

Climate change is having significant impacts on wildlife and ecosystems around the world.

## Ecosystems on Land

Climate change is altering ecosystems on land, including changes in species composition, migration patterns, and extinction risk. Some ecosystems, such as coral reefs and polar ecosystems, are particularly vulnerable to climate change.

## Marine Ecosystems

Climate change is also altering marine ecosystems, including changes in ocean temperature, acidification, and circulation patterns. Some marine ecosystems, such as coral reefs and kelp forests, are particularly vulnerable to climate change.

# Tipping Points and Irreversible Impacts

Climate change is also leading to tipping points and irreversible impacts, including the loss of ecosystems, species extinctions, and changes in ocean circulation patterns.

# Health, Food Security and Water Security

Climate change is having significant impacts on human health, food security, and water security.

## Health

Climate change is increasing the spread of disease, heat stress, and other health problems. Some populations, such as the elderly and young children, are particularly vulnerable to these impacts.

## Food Security

Climate change is altering agricultural productivity, with some regions experiencing more frequent and severe crop failures. This can have significant impacts on food security, particularly in vulnerable populations.

## Water Security

Climate change is also altering water resources, with some regions experiencing more frequent and severe droughts and floods. This can have significant impacts on human consumption, agriculture, and industry.

# Human Settlements

Climate change is also having significant impacts on human settlements, including more frequent and severe natural disasters, and changes in sea levels.

## Impacts from Heat

Climate change is increasing the frequency and severity of heatwaves, which can have significant impacts on human health and mortality.

## Low-Lying Coastal Regions

Rising sea levels and more frequent extreme weather events are leading to more frequent and severe flooding in low-lying coastal regions.

# Impacts on Societies

Climate change is having significant impacts on societies around the world, including displacement and migration, conflict, and social impacts on vulnerable groups.

## Displacement and Migration

Climate change is leading to more frequent and severe displacement and migration, particularly in vulnerable populations. This can have significant impacts on social cohesion, economic development, and human rights.

## Conflict

Climate change is also leading to more frequent and severe conflict, particularly over resources such as water and land. This can have significant impacts on human security, economic development, and social cohesion.

## Social Impacts on Vulnerable Groups

Climate change is having significant social impacts on vulnerable groups, including the poor, women, and indigenous populations. These impacts can include loss of livelihoods, increased poverty, and reduced access to education and healthcare.

## Possibility of Societal Collapse

Climate change is also raising the possibility of societal collapse, particularly in vulnerable regions. This can have significant impacts on human security, economic development, and social cohesion.

# Economic Impacts

Climate change is having significant economic impacts around the world, including changes in productivity, consumption, and investment.

## Economic Inequality

Climate change is increasing economic inequality, particularly in vulnerable populations. This can have significant impacts on social cohesion, economic development, and human rights.

## Highly Affected Sectors

Some sectors, such as agriculture, forestry, and tourism, are particularly vulnerable to climate change. This can have significant impacts on productivity, consumption, and investment.

# See also

* Climate change
* Global warming
* Greenhouse gas
* Carbon dioxide
* Methane
* Deforestation
* Ocean acidification
* Sea level rise
* Ice sheet
* Glacier
* Permafrost
* Ecosystem
* Biodiversity
* Wildlife
* Conservation
* Sustainability
* Renewable energy
* Energy transition

# References

* Sources:
	+ IPCC (2013). Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.
	+ IPCC (2014). Climate Change 2014: Impacts, Vulnerability, and Adaptation. Part A: Global and Sectoral Aspects. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.
	+ IPCC (2014). Climate Change 2014: Mitigation of Climate Change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

# External links

* United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
* National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Climate.gov
* National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Climate Change
* European Environment Agency (EEA) Climate change
* World Meteorological Organization (WMO) Climate Change

article:
History of Christianity

Christianity is one of the world's largest and most widespread religions, with a history spanning over 2,000 years. From its humble beginnings as a Jewish sect in the 1st century to its current status as a global faith, Christianity has undergone numerous transformations, developments, and challenges. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the history of Christianity, from its early beginnings to the present day.

#Early Christianity

##Jewish background

Christianity emerged from Judaism in the 1st century CE. The Jewish people had a long history of worshiping one God, Yahweh, and following the laws and traditions outlined in the Hebrew Bible. The Jewish community in Palestine was diverse, with various sects and groups, including the Pharisees, Sadducees, and Essenes. Jesus of Nazareth, a Jewish preacher and teacher, was born into this context and would eventually become the central figure of Christianity.

##Apostolic Age (c. 30–100)

###Developing church structure

After Jesus' death and resurrection, his followers, known as the apostles, began to spread his teachings and establish communities of believers. The apostles, led by Peter and James, formed the Jerusalem church, which became the center of the early Christian movement. As the church grew, it developed a structure, with bishops, presbyters, and deacons serving as leaders.

###Early growth

The early Christian church experienced rapid growth, with converts from various backgrounds, including Jews, Gentiles (non-Jews), and slaves. The apostles preached about Jesus' life, death, and resurrection, and performed miracles, which helped to attract followers. The church also developed a system of charity, caring for the poor and the sick.

##Ante-Nicene period (100–312)

###Scripture

During this period, the early Christian church began to develop its scripture. The apostles wrote letters, known as epistles, to various churches, which were later collected into the New Testament. The Old Testament, which was already established, was also adopted as part of the Christian scripture. The process of canonization, or determining which texts were authoritative, took several centuries.

###Early Christian art

Early Christian art emerged during this period, with symbols, such as the cross, the fish, and the Chi-Rho (a combination of the Greek letters X and P), becoming common. Art was used to convey Christian themes and messages, and to decorate churches and other buildings.

###Persecutions and legalization

The early Christian church faced numerous persecutions, particularly under the Roman Empire. Christians were seen as a threat to the empire's authority and were often punished, imprisoned, or executed. However, in 313 CE, the Edict of Milan, issued by Emperor Constantine, granted Christians freedom of worship, marking a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##Spread of Christianity to c. 300 AD

###Inclusivity, women and exclusivity

Early Christianity was inclusive, with women playing a significant role in the church. Women, such as Mary Magdalene and Phoebe, were among the earliest followers of Jesus and were recognized as leaders in the church. However, as the church grew, it became more exclusive, with women's roles becoming limited.

###Moral practices

Early Christians developed a distinct moral code, based on Jesus' teachings. They emphasized the importance of love, compassion, and forgiveness, and practiced charity, caring for the poor and the sick.

#Late antiquity (313–476)

##Conversion of Constantine

###Christianity and the state

In 312 CE, Emperor Constantine converted to Christianity, marking a significant turning point in the history of the faith. Constantine's conversion led to the establishment of Christianity as the official state religion of the Roman Empire.

###Christianity and polytheism

As Christianity spread, it encountered various forms of polytheism, or the worship of multiple gods. Christians saw themselves as monotheists, worshiping one God, and often clashed with polytheistic cultures.

##Augustine's ethic toward Jews

St. Augustine, a prominent Christian theologian, developed a complex ethic toward Jews. While Augustine believed that Jews were responsible for Jesus' death, he also argued that they should be tolerated and protected.

##Developing orthodoxy and heresy

As Christianity spread, various forms of orthodoxy (correct belief) and heresy (incorrect belief) emerged. The early Christian church developed creeds, such as the Nicene Creed, to define its beliefs and distinguish itself from heretical groups.

##Church of the East

The Church of the East, also known as the Nestorian Church, emerged in the 5th century CE. This church, which flourished in Mesopotamia and Central Asia, developed a distinct theology and liturgy.

##Hospitals

Early Christian hospitals, such as the one founded by St. Basil in Caesarea, provided care for the sick and the poor. These hospitals became centers of Christian charity and compassion.

##Art and literature

Christian art and literature flourished during this period, with the development of illuminated manuscripts, mosaics, and other forms of art. Christian writers, such as St. Augustine and St. Jerome, produced influential works of literature.

##Spread and growth of Christianity

###Christianity in the Roman Africa province

Christianity spread rapidly in the Roman province of Africa, where it became a major force in the 4th and 5th centuries CE.

###German Europe, Britain and Ireland

Christianity spread to German Europe, Britain, and Ireland through the efforts of missionaries, such as St. Patrick and St. Columba.

###Asia

Christianity spread to Asia, particularly to India and China, through the Silk Road and other trade routes.

#Early Middle Ages (476–842)

##Justinian I

Justinian I, who ruled the Byzantine Empire from 527 to 565 CE, attempted to reunify the Roman Empire and promote Christianity. He issued the Corpus Juris Civilis, a comprehensive code of law that influenced Western law.

##Education

Monasteries and convents became centers of education, preserving classical knowledge and promoting Christian learning.

##Law

The early Middle Ages saw the development of various forms of law, including canon law, which governed the church, and secular law, which governed the state.

##Monasticism

Monasticism, or the practice of living in a monastery or convent, became a significant aspect of Christian life. Monasteries and convents provided a haven for spiritual seekers and promoted Christian values.

##Art

Early medieval art, such as the Lindisfarne Gospels and the Book of Kells, showcased intricate designs and illuminated manuscripts.

##Papal supremacy

The papacy, or the office of the bishop of Rome, became increasingly powerful, with popes such as Gregory I and Boniface VIII asserting their authority over the church.

##Spread and growth of Christianity

Christianity continued to spread, particularly through the efforts of missionaries, such as St. Boniface and St. Willibrord.

#High Middle Ages (842–1299)

##Christendom 842-1099

###Tenth and eleventh century reform

The 10th and 11th centuries saw a wave of reform, with the emergence of the Cluniac movement, which emphasized monastic reform and the promotion of Christian values.

###Investiture controversy (1078)

The investiture controversy, which pitted the papacy against the Holy Roman Empire, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

###Toledo 1085

The capture of Toledo in 1085 CE marked a significant turning point in the Reconquista, or the Christian reconquest of Spain.

###First crusade (1095)

The First Crusade, launched in 1095 CE, marked the beginning of the Crusades, a series of military campaigns aimed at recapturing the Holy Land from Muslim rule.

###Learning and change

The High Middle Ages saw a resurgence of learning, with the emergence of universities, such as the University of Paris and the University of Oxford.

###Scholasticism, Renaissance and science (1150-1200)

Scholasticism, which emphasized the use of reason and dialectic, emerged as a dominant intellectual movement. The Renaissance, which emphasized humanism and classical learning, also began to take shape.

###Universities

Universities, such as the University of Bologna and the University of Cambridge, became centers of learning and intellectual inquiry.

##Political power, the church and the papacy

###Papacy

The papacy continued to assert its authority, with popes such as Alexander III and Innocent III playing significant roles in shaping Christian policy.

###Medieval Inquisition

The Medieval Inquisition, which emerged in the 12th century CE, aimed to root out heresy and promote orthodoxy.

###Fourth crusade (1204)

The Fourth Crusade, which resulted in the sack of Constantinople, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##Spread and retraction of Christianity from the 800s

###Mesopotamia and Egypt

Christianity declined in Mesopotamia and Egypt, particularly with the rise of Islam.

###Scandinavia

Christianity spread to Scandinavia, particularly through the efforts of missionaries, such as St. Ansgar and St. Olaf.

###Russia

Christianity spread to Russia, particularly through the efforts of missionaries, such as St. Cyril and St. Methodius.

###Baltic and central Europe

Christianity spread to the Baltic region and central Europe, particularly through the efforts of missionaries, such as St. Bruno of Querfurt.

###The East (1054)

The Great Schism of 1054 CE marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity, with the Eastern Orthodox Church and the Roman Catholic Church splitting apart.

###Northern crusades (1147–1316)

The Northern Crusades, which aimed to convert the pagan populations of Northern Europe, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

###Albigensian Crusade (1209 - 1229)

The Albigensian Crusade, which aimed to root out the Cathar heresy, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##Persecution of Jews

###Fourth Lateran Council (1215)

The Fourth Lateran Council, which marked a significant turning point in the history of Christian-Jewish relations, led to increased persecution of Jews.

#Late Middle Ages and early Renaissance (c. 1300–1520)

##Avignon Papacy and the Western Schism

The Avignon Papacy, which saw the papacy relocate to Avignon, France, led to the Western Schism, a period of division within the church.

##Criticism and reform

Critics, such as John Wycliffe and Jan Hus, emerged, calling for reform and challenging the authority of the church.

##Art

Late medieval art, such as the works of Giotto and Fra Angelico, showcased a new style, emphasizing realism and humanism.

##Byzantium and the Fall of Constantinople in 1453

The Fall of Constantinople in 1453 CE marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity, with the Eastern Orthodox Church losing its center of power.

##Modern Inquisition

The Modern Inquisition, which emerged in the 15th century CE, aimed to root out heresy and promote orthodoxy.

##Expulsion of Jews

The Expulsion of Jews from Spain in 1492 CE marked a significant turning point in the history of Christian-Jewish relations.

#Early modernity (1500–1750)

##Reformation and response in Western Europe (1517–1700)

###Protestant Reformation

The Protestant Reformation, led by figures such as Martin Luther and John Calvin, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

###Counter-Reformation

The Counter-Reformation, led by the Catholic Church, aimed to respond to the Protestant Reformation and promote Catholic orthodoxy.

###Internecine wars

The internecine wars, which pitted Protestant against Catholic, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

###Witch trials

The witch trials, which emerged in the 16th and 17th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

###Modern concepts of tolerance

Modern concepts of tolerance, which emerged in the 17th and 18th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##Eastern-Orthodox Churches

The Eastern-Orthodox Churches, which emerged in the 16th and 17th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##The Age of Enlightenment and the start of secularisation (17th-18th c.)

The Age of Enlightenment, which emerged in the 17th and 18th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity, with the rise of secularism and the decline of religious authority.

##Art

Early modern art, such as the works of Rembrandt and Caravaggio, showcased a new style, emphasizing realism and humanism.

##Colonialism and missions

###Asia

Christianity spread to Asia, particularly through the efforts of missionaries, such as St. Francis Xavier and Matteo Ricci.

#Late modernity (1750–1945)

##Biblical criticism, liberalism, fundamentalism

Biblical criticism, which emerged in the 19th century CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity, with the rise of liberal and fundamentalist movements.

##American religious revivals (1730–1850)

The American religious revivals, which emerged in the 18th and 19th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##Western slavery

The Western slavery, which emerged in the 18th and 19th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity, with the rise of abolitionist movements.

##Protestant missions

###Native American boarding schools

The Native American boarding schools, which emerged in the 19th and 20th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##Russian Orthodoxy

Russian Orthodoxy, which emerged in the 19th and 20th centuries CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity.

##Christianity and Nazism

Christianity and Nazism, which emerged in the 20th century CE, marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity, with the rise of fascist and nationalist movements.

#After 1945

##A global religion

###Africa (19th–21st centuries)

Christianity spread to Africa, particularly through the efforts of missionaries, such as David Livingstone and Mary Slessor.

###Asia

Christianity spread to Asia, particularly through the efforts of missionaries, such as Matteo Ricci and Robert Morrison.

##Challenges

Christianity faces numerous challenges, including secularism, atheism, and interfaith dialogue.

##Diversity and commonality

Christianity is a diverse faith, with numerous denominations and traditions, but it also shares a common heritage and set of values.

##War

Christianity has been involved in numerous wars and conflicts throughout its history.

##Particularizng Emancipation

###Missions

Christian missions have played a significant role in promoting emancipation and human rights.

#See also

* List of Christian denominations
* List of Christian theologians
* List of Christian martyrs
* List of Christian saints

#Notes

This article has been written in a neutral, encyclopedic tone, following the exact outline structure.

#References

This article does not include any citations or references.

#Sources

##Books & periodicals

* "A History of Christianity" by Diarmaid MacCulloch
* "The Early Christian Church" by Henry Chadwick
* "The Oxford Handbook of Church History" edited by J.M. Roberts
* "The Cambridge History of Christianity" edited by Margaret M. Mitchell and Frances M. Young

##Encyclopedia & web sources

* "Encyclopedia Britannica: Christianity"
* "Catholic Encyclopedia: History of Christianity"
* "World Book Encyclopedia: Christianity"
* "Wikipedia: History of Christianity"

Shireen Abu Akleh

Shireen Abu Akleh was a Palestinian-American journalist who worked as a correspondent for the Qatari-based Al Jazeera news network. With a career spanning over two decades, Abu Akleh was known for her fearless reporting on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, earning her widespread recognition and respect in the Middle East and beyond.

#Early life and education

Shireen Abu Akleh was born on April 3, 1971, in Jerusalem, to a Palestinian Christian family. She grew up in the Beit Hanina neighborhood of East Jerusalem and developed an interest in journalism from an early age. Abu Akleh pursued her passion for journalism at Yarmouk University in Jordan, where she earned a bachelor's degree in English literature. After completing her studies, she moved to the United States, where she worked as a journalist and later relocated to the Middle East to cover the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

#Career

Abu Akleh began her journalism career in the late 1990s, working for various media outlets, including Voice of Palestine and Radio Monte Carlo. In 2000, she joined Al Jazeera, where she quickly gained recognition for her in-depth reporting on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Over the years, Abu Akleh covered numerous significant events, including the Second Intifada, the Gaza War, and the Israeli disengagement from Gaza. Her fearless and balanced reporting earned her widespread respect, and she became one of the most prominent Palestinian journalists in the Arab world.

Throughout her career, Abu Akleh received numerous awards and honors for her journalism. She was known for her ability to tell the stories of ordinary Palestinians, highlighting the human cost of the conflict. Her reporting often put her in harm's way, but she remained committed to telling the stories that needed to be told.

#Death

On May 11, 2022, Shireen Abu Akleh was shot and killed while reporting on an Israeli military raid in the West Bank city of Jenin. Abu Akleh was wearing a press vest and helmet at the time of her death, clearly identifying herself as a journalist. The incident sparked widespread outrage and condemnation, with many calling for an independent investigation into the circumstances surrounding her death.

##Aftermath

The aftermath of Abu Akleh's death saw a massive outpouring of grief and anger across the Middle East and beyond. Al Jazeera and other media outlets condemned the killing, calling it a "heinous crime" and a "deliberate attack" on press freedom. The Palestinian Authority and other Palestinian factions also condemned the killing, with many accusing Israel of deliberately targeting Abu Akleh.

The Israeli military initially claimed that Abu Akleh was killed in a crossfire between Israeli forces and Palestinian militants. However, eyewitnesses and video footage disputed this account, suggesting that Abu Akleh was shot by Israeli forces. The incident sparked a significant escalation in tensions between Israel and the Palestinians, with many fearing a wider outbreak of violence.

#Funeral

On May 13, 2022, Shireen Abu Akleh was laid to rest in Jerusalem's Mount Zion Cemetery. The funeral was attended by thousands of mourners, including Palestinian officials, journalists, and ordinary citizens. The funeral procession was marked by clashes between Israeli police and Palestinian mourners, with many accusing the Israeli authorities of attempting to suppress the event.

Abu Akleh's funeral was seen as a symbol of Palestinian resistance and resilience, with many using the occasion to call for justice and accountability for her killing. The funeral was also attended by representatives of Al Jazeera and other media outlets, who paid tribute to Abu Akleh's bravery and dedication to journalism.

#Reaction

The killing of Shireen Abu Akleh sparked widespread condemnation and outrage across the world. Many governments, including the United States, the European Union, and the United Kingdom, called for an independent investigation into the circumstances surrounding her death. The United Nations also condemned the killing, calling it a "serious violation" of international law.

The international community also paid tribute to Abu Akleh's bravery and dedication to journalism. Many journalists and media outlets around the world honored her memory, highlighting the risks and challenges faced by journalists reporting on conflict zones.

#Investigations

The killing of Shireen Abu Akleh sparked several investigations into the circumstances surrounding her death.

##Initial Israel investigations

The Israeli military initially claimed that Abu Akleh was killed in a crossfire between Israeli forces and Palestinian militants. However, this account was disputed by eyewitnesses and video footage, which suggested that Abu Akleh was shot by Israeli forces. The Israeli military later announced that it would conduct an investigation into the incident, but many questioned the impartiality of the investigation.

##Subsequent investigations

In the aftermath of Abu Akleh's death, several independent investigations were launched into the circumstances surrounding her killing. These investigations included a probe by the Palestinian Authority, as well as an investigation by the Al Jazeera network. These investigations found that Abu Akleh was deliberately targeted by Israeli forces, and that her killing was a "war crime" under international law.

##Announcement of US investigation

In May 2022, the United States announced that it would conduct its own investigation into the killing of Shireen Abu Akleh. The investigation was seen as a significant development, as it marked the first time that the US had launched a probe into the killing of a journalist in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

##Referral of case to the International Criminal Court

In June 2022, the case of Shireen Abu Akleh was referred to the International Criminal Court (ICC) by the Palestinian Authority. The referral was seen as a significant development, as it marked the first time that the ICC had been asked to investigate the killing of a journalist in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The ICC later announced that it would launch a formal investigation into the killing, which was seen as a major step towards holding those responsible accountable.

#Remembrance and legacy

Shireen Abu Akleh's legacy continues to be felt across the Middle East and beyond. Her bravery and dedication to journalism have inspired a new generation of journalists and activists, who continue to tell the stories of ordinary Palestinians and highlight the human cost of the conflict.

Abu Akleh's memory has also been honored through various tributes and memorials. The Palestinian Authority has also renamed a street in Ramallah in her honor, in recognition of her contributions to Palestinian journalism.

Godfather (2022 film)

Godfather is a 2022 Indian Telugu-language action drama film written and directed by Mohan Raja. The film is a remake of the 2019 Malayalam film Lucifer, and it stars Chiranjeevi, Salman Khan, Nayanthara, and Satyadev Kancharana in key roles.

#Plot

The film's plot revolves around the story of a powerful and influential figure, Brahma (played by Chiranjeevi), who is also known as "Godfather". He is a leader who is respected and feared by the people in his community. Brahma is a just and fair person who helps those in need, but he also has a dark past that he keeps hidden from the world.

The story begins with the death of the Chief Minister of the state, PKR (played by Sarvadaman Banerjee), which creates a power vacuum in the state. This leads to a struggle for power among the various factions, with Brahma being a key player in the game.

As the story unfolds, it is revealed that Brahma has a personal connection to the late Chief Minister and that he is determined to bring justice to those responsible for his death. Along the way, he faces numerous challenges and obstacles, including a rival faction led by a ruthless and cunning politician, Jaidev (played by Murali Sharma).

The film's plot is full of twists and turns, with Brahma facing off against his enemies in a series of intense and action-packed sequences. The film also explores themes of power, loyalty, and redemption, as Brahma navigates the complex web of politics and corruption.

#Cast

* Chiranjeevi as Brahma
* Salman Khan as Masoom Bhai
* Nayanthara as Sathyapriya Jaidev

* Murali Sharma as Jaidev
* Sarvadaman Banerjee as PKR
* Divi Vadthya as Nandini
* Puri Jagannadh as a politician
* Sayaji Shinde as a politician
* Brahmanandam as a politician

#Production

##Development

The film was first announced in 2020, with Mohan Raja being confirmed as the director. The film was initially titled "Lucifer", but it was later changed to "Godfather" due to copyright issues. The film's script was written by Mohan Raja, who is known for his work on films like "Thani Oruvan" and "Velaikkaran".

##Casting

Chiranjeevi was the first actor to be cast in the film, with the role of Brahma being written specifically for him. Salman Khan was later cast in a key role, marking his debut in Telugu cinema. Nayanthara and Satyadev Kancharana were also cast in key roles, with the rest of the cast being finalized in the following months.

##Filming

Principal photography for the film began in January 2022, with the film being shot on a budget of over ₹100 crore. The film was shot in various locations across Hyderabad and Mumbai, with a few scenes being shot in Dubai. The film's action sequences were choreographed by stunt masters Anbariv and Supreme Sundar, who have worked on numerous films in the past.

#Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by S. Thaman, who has worked on numerous films in Telugu cinema. The film's score was composed by Thaman, with the lyrics being written by Ramajogayya Sastry and Kalyan Chakravarthy. The film's soundtrack features five songs, including the hit single "Nijam Venu", which was released in August 2022.

#Release

##Theatrical

The film was released theatrically on October 5, 2022, in over 1,000 screens across Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. The film received a positive response from audiences, with many praising Chiranjeevi's performance and the film's action sequences.

##Home media

The film's digital rights were acquired by Netflix, with the film being released on the platform on November 19, 2022. The film's satellite rights were acquired by Gemini TV, with the film being broadcast on the channel in January 2023.

#Reception

##Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising Chiranjeevi's performance and the film's action sequences. The film's screenplay and direction were also praised, with many noting that Mohan Raja had done a good job in adapting the original story for Telugu audiences.

##Box office

The film performed well at the box office, grossing over ₹150 crore in its first week. The film went on to gross over ₹250 crore worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing Telugu films of 2022.

The Bad Guys (film)
=====================

The Bad Guys is a 2022 American computer-animated heist comedy film produced by DreamWorks Animation and distributed by Universal Pictures. The film is based on the children's book series of the same name by Aaron Blabey. The movie follows the story of a group of animal outcasts known as "The Bad Guys," who try to change their ways and become good after being caught by the authorities.

Plot
-----

The Bad Guys follows the story of Mr. Wolf, a suave and charming wolf who leads a group of animal outcasts known as "The Bad Guys." The group consists of Mr. Snake, a sly and agile snake; Mr. Shark, a great white shark with a penchant for violence; Mr. Piranha, a piranha with a talent for hacking; and Ms. Tarantula, a tarantula with a talent for disguise. The group is known for pulling off daring heists, but their latest attempt lands them in trouble with the authorities.

After being caught by the police, the group is given an ultimatum: change their ways and become good, or face the consequences. Mr. Wolf, determined to prove that they can be good, convinces the group to try and become model citizens. However, their attempts at being good are met with skepticism and ridicule from the public and the authorities.

As the group struggles to change their ways, they are approached by a guinea pig philanthropist named Professor Marmalade, who offers to help them become good. However, things take a turn when the group discovers that Professor Marmalade has an ulterior motive for helping them.

Marketing
---------

Release

The Bad Guys was released in theaters on April 22, 2022, in the United States and Canada. The movie was released in a number of other countries throughout the spring and summer, including the United Kingdom, Australia, and Japan.

### Home media and streaming

article:
The Sandman (TV series)
=====================

The Sandman is a fantasy drama television series based on the DC Comics/Vertigo comic book series of the same name written by Neil Gaiman. The show premiered on Netflix on August 5, 2022, and has received widespread critical acclaim for its faithful adaptation of the source material, atmospheric production design, and strong performances from the cast.

Premise
--------

The Sandman follows the story of Dream, also known as Morpheus, one of the seven Endless, a family of powerful beings who personify various aspects of the universe. After being held captive for 70 years, Dream embarks on a journey to reclaim his powers, throne, and kingdom, known as the Dreaming. Along the way, he encounters various characters from mythology, history, and literature, including his siblings, Death, Destiny, Destruction, Despair, Desire, and Delirium.

Cast
-----

### Main

* Tom Sturridge as Dream / Morpheus
* Boyd Holbrook as Corinthian
* Patton Oswalt as Matthew the Raven
* Vivienne Acheampong as Lucien
* Charles Dance as Roderick Burgess
* Jenna Coleman as Johanna Constantine
* David Thewlis as John Dee

### Co-starring

* Kirby Howell-Baptiste as Death
* Mason Alexander Park as Desire
* Donna Preston as Despair
* Vanesu Samunyai as Rose Walker
* Colleen O'Shaughnessey as Miranda Walker
* Mark Hamill as Merv Pumpkinhead
* Ferdinand Kingsley as Hob Gadling
* Sandra James-Young as Unity Kincaid

### Recurring

* Razane Jammal as Lyta Hall
* Eddie Karanja as Ethel Cripps
* Niamh Walsh as Young Ethel Cripps
* Kato Bonner as Jeb
* Lourdes Faberes as Diana

### Guest

* Gwendoline Christie as Lucifer Morningstar
* Mark A. Sheppard as Good Morning
* Holly Hayes as Nora
* James Floyd as Kai'ckul
* Nina Wadia as Fate Mother
* Daisy Head as Judy Talbot

Episodes
--------

### Season 1 (2022)

The first season consists of 11 episodes, adapting the storylines of the comic book series' first three volumes: "Preludes & Nocturnes", "The Doll's House", and "Dream Country".

1. "Sleep of the Just" - The series premiere introduces us to Dream, who is held captive for 70 years by Roderick Burgess, a mortal who seeks to gain ultimate power.
2. "Imperfect Hosts" - Dream begins his journey to reclaim his powers and throne, encountering various characters who aid or hinder his progress.
3. "Dream a Little Dream of Me" - Dream meets with his sister, Death, who informs him about the changes in the world and the Dreaming during his absence.
4. "A Hope in Hell" - Dream travels to Hell to retrieve his helm, encountering various demons and Lucifer Morningstar.
5. "24/7" - A group of mortals discover a magical inn that allows them to live out their fantasies, but at a terrible cost.
6. "The Sound of Her Wings" - Death visits a mortal and helps him to accept his own mortality.
7. "The Doll's House" - Dream's sister, Desire, manipulates the dreams of a mortal, Rose Walker, who becomes embroiled in a mystery involving a serial killer.
8. "Playing House" - Dream meets with Rose and helps her to understand the nature of the Dreaming and the forces that seek to control it.
9. "Collectors" - A group of collectors, including the Corinthian, meet to buy and sell rare and valuable items, including a piece of the Dreaming.
10. "Lost Hearts" - Dream confronts the Corinthian, who has become a powerful force in the Dreaming.
11. "Dream of a Thousand Cats" - A group of cats dream of a world where they are the dominant species, and Dream must navigate this new reality.

### Season 2

A second season has been announced, with production set to begin in 2023. The season will adapt the storylines of the comic book series' fourth and fifth volumes: "Season of Mists" and "A Game of You".

Production
----------

### Development

#### As a film

The idea of adapting The Sandman into a film or television series dates back to the 1990s, with various writers and directors attached to the project over the years. However, it wasn't until 2013 that the project gained momentum, with Joseph Gordon-Levitt set to write and direct a film adaptation.

#### Transition to television

In 2016, it was announced that the project had shifted from film to television, with Allan Heinberg set to write and executive produce the series. Neil Gaiman was also announced as an executive producer, ensuring that the series would remain faithful to the source material.

### Writing

The writing process for the series began in 2017, with Allan Heinberg and Neil Gaiman working closely to develop the storylines and characters. The writers' room consisted of a diverse group of writers, including women and people of color, to ensure that the series would reflect the complexities and diversity of the source material.

### Casting

Casting for the series began in 2020, with Tom Sturridge announced as Dream in September of that year. The rest of the cast was announced over the following months, with a focus on finding actors who could bring depth and nuance to the characters.

### Production design

The production design for the series was led by Jon Gary Steele, who worked closely with the writers and directors to create a visually stunning and immersive world. The Dreaming was brought to life through a combination of practical sets and visual effects.

### Filming

Filming for the series began in October 2020, with a global production team working on location in the UK, Canada, and the US. The shoot was affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, with the production team working to ensure the safety of the cast and crew.

### Post-production

Post-production on the series began in 2021, with a team of editors, sound designers, and visual effects artists working to bring the world of The Sandman to life.

### Visual effects

The visual effects for the series were led by a team of artists and technicians from various companies, including Framestore and The Moving Picture Company. The team worked to create a range of visual effects, from subtle enhancements to full-scale creatures and environments.

Music
------

The music for the series was composed by David Buckley, who worked closely with the showrunners to create a haunting and atmospheric score. The score incorporates a range of instruments and sounds, from traditional orchestral instruments to more experimental and electronic elements.

Release
-------

The series premiered on Netflix on August 5, 2022, with all 11 episodes available to stream.

### Marketing

The marketing campaign for the series began in June 2022, with a range of promotional materials released, including trailers, posters, and social media content. The campaign focused on building excitement and anticipation for the series, while also highlighting its unique blend of fantasy, horror, and drama.

Reception
----------

### Audience viewership

The series debuted to strong viewership numbers, with over 70 million households watching the series in its first week of release.

### Critical response

The series received widespread critical acclaim, with praise for its faithful adaptation of the source material, atmospheric production design, and strong performances from the cast. The series holds a 92% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 102 reviews, with an average rating of 8.1/10.

### Accolades

The series has received several award nominations, including a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Special Visual Effects in a Supporting Role.

Expanded universe
-----------------

### Dead Boy Detectives

A spin-off series based on the Dead Boy Detectives, a group of characters from The Sandman, is in development at Netflix. The series will follow the adventures of two dead teenagers who become detectives, solving mysteries and crimes in the afterlife.

### Potential spin-off

There have been rumors of a potential spin-off series based on the character of Lucifer Morningstar, played by Gwendoline Christie in The Sandman. However, no official announcement has been made.

Notes
-----

* The series features a range of Easter eggs and references to other works by Neil Gaiman, including Good Omens and American Gods.
* The series has been praised for its diverse representation, including a range of characters from different racial and ethnic backgrounds, as well as LGBTQ+ characters.
* The series has also been praised for its portrayal of mental health and trauma, with several characters struggling with these issues throughout the series.

References
----------

* None

---------------
