article:
Cinema of Russia

The cinema of Russia has a long and rich history, spanning over a century. From the early days of the Russian Empire to the modern era, Russian cinema has produced some of the most influential and iconic films in the world. This article will explore the history of Russian cinema, from its early beginnings to the present day, including its development during the Soviet era, the emergence of new Russian cinema, and the current state of the industry.

# Cinema of the Russian Empire

The cinema of the Russian Empire began in the late 19th century, with the first film screenings taking place in 1896. The early days of Russian cinema were marked by a fascination with the new technology, and films were often shown as part of vaudeville shows or as a novelty attraction. As the industry developed, Russian filmmakers began to produce their own films, often using literary classics as source material.

One of the most influential filmmakers of this period was Alexander Khanzhonkov, who is considered to be the founder of Russian cinema. Khanzhonkov's films, such as "The Defense of Sevastopol" (1911), were known for their high production values and their use of location shooting. Another notable filmmaker of this period was Yakov Protasanov, who directed films such as "The Queen of Spades" (1916).

# Cinema of the Soviet Union

The cinema of the Soviet Union was born in the aftermath of the Russian Revolution, and it quickly became a powerful tool for propaganda and social commentary. The Soviet government saw cinema as a way to reach a wide audience and to promote its ideology, and it invested heavily in the film industry.

## Early Soviet cinema (1917–1953)

The early years of Soviet cinema were marked by a series of experiments with form and content. Filmmakers such as Sergei Eisenstein and Dziga Vertov pushed the boundaries of what was possible on screen, using montage and other techniques to create a new kind of cinema.

Eisenstein's "Battleship Potemkin" (1925) is considered one of the greatest films of all time, and it is still studied by film students around the world. Vertov's "Man with a Movie Camera" (1929) is another influential film of this period, and it is known for its use of montage and its exploration of the relationship between the camera and reality.

## Late Soviet cinema (1953–1990)

The late Soviet period saw a decline in the experimental spirit of early Soviet cinema, and films became more conventional and more focused on storytelling. However, this period also saw the emergence of some of the greatest filmmakers of the Soviet era, including Andrei Tarkovsky and Nikita Mikhalkov.

Tarkovsky's films, such as "Andrei Rublev" (1966) and "Solaris" (1972), are known for their philosophical and poetic themes, as well as their use of long takes and other unconventional techniques. Mikhalkov's films, such as "Five Evenings" (1978) and "Oblomov" (1980), are known for their nuanced portrayals of Soviet life and their use of satire and social commentary.

# New Russian cinema

The collapse of the Soviet Union saw a decline in the Russian film industry, but it also created new opportunities for filmmakers. The emergence of new Russian cinema in the 1990s saw a new generation of filmmakers exploring new themes and new styles.

## 1990s

The 1990s saw the emergence of filmmakers such as Pavel Lungin and Alexander Sokurov. Lungin's films, such as "Taxi Blues" (1990) and "Luna Park" (1992), are known for their gritty portrayals of Russian life and their use of social commentary. Sokurov's films, such as "Days of the Eclipse" (1988) and "Whispers of the Empire" (1993), are known for their poetic and philosophical themes, as well as their use of unconventional techniques.

## 2000s

The 2000s saw the emergence of filmmakers such as Timur Bekmambetov and Alexey Balabanov. Bekmambetov's films, such as "Night Watch" (2004) and "Day Watch" (2006), are known for their use of action and fantasy elements, as well as their exploration of Russian mythology. Balabanov's films, such as "Brat" (1997) and "Of Freaks and Men" (1998), are known for their dark and subversive portrayals of Russian life.

## 2010s

The 2010s saw the emergence of filmmakers such as Andrey Zvyagintsev and Kirill Serebrennikov. Zvyagintsev's films, such as "Leviathan" (2014) and "Loveless" (2017), are known for their nuanced portrayals of Russian life and their use of social commentary. Serebrennikov's films, such as "The Student" (2016) and "Summer" (2018), are known for their use of satire and their exploration of Russian youth culture.

## 2020s

The 2020s have seen a new generation of Russian filmmakers emerge, including Kantemir Balagov and Ivan Tverdovsky. Balagov's films, such as "Closeness" (2017) and "Beanpole" (2019), are known for their poetic and philosophical themes, as well as their use of unconventional techniques. Tverdovsky's films, such as "Zoology" (2016) and "Jumpman" (2018), are known for their use of satire and their exploration of Russian middle-class life.

### 2022 boycott

In 2022, a number of Russian filmmakers, including Zvyagintsev and Serebrennikov, publicly boycotted the Russian film industry in response to the country's invasion of Ukraine. The boycott was seen as a significant blow to the Russian film industry, and it highlighted the ongoing challenges faced by Russian filmmakers in the current political climate.

article:
International Women's Day
==========================

International Women's Day (IWD) is celebrated on March 8 every year. It is a global day to recognize the social, economic, cultural, and political achievements of women. The day also marks a call to action for accelerating women's equality and is often marked with events and rallies around the world.

History
--------

### Origins

The origins of International Women's Day date back to the early 20th century. In 1908, 15,000 women marched through New York City demanding better pay, shorter hours, and voting rights. In 1910, the International Conference of Socialist Women was held in Copenhagen, Denmark, where Clara Zetkin, a German socialist, proposed the idea of an International Women's Day.

### The Russian Revolution and Communist countries

In 1917, following the Russian Revolution, the first International Women's Day was celebrated in Russia on the last Sunday in February. After the revolution, the day was celebrated annually in Russia and other communist countries. In 1921, the Communist International (Comintern) officially declared March 8 as International Women's Day.

### Other countries, 1920s to 1960s

In the 1920s and 1930s, International Women's Day was celebrated in several countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia. However, the day gained little attention in the West until the 1960s, when the feminist movement began to gain momentum.

### Second–wave feminism

The second-wave feminist movement of the 1960s and 1970s helped to revive interest in International Women's Day. In 1975, the United Nations (UN) declared 1975 as International Women's Year, and March 8 was officially recognized as International Women's Day.

### Adoption by United Nations

In 1977, the United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution proclaiming March 8 as the UN Day for Women's Rights and International Peace. Since then, the UN has played a significant role in promoting International Women's Day.

### Adoption by corporations

In recent years, International Women's Day has gained significant attention from corporations and brands. Many companies now celebrate the day with events, campaigns, and social media promotions.

International Women's Day by year
--------------------------------

### 1995

In 1995, the UN Conference on Women in Beijing adopted the Beijing Platform for Action, a comprehensive plan to achieve gender equality.

### 1996

In 1996, the UN launched the UNIFEM (United Nations Development Fund for Women) campaign, which aimed to promote women's empowerment and gender equality.

### 2003

In 2003, the UN launched the UNIFEM "Not a Minute More" campaign, which aimed to raise awareness about violence against women.

### 2006

In 2006, the UN launched the "Unite to End Violence against Women" campaign, which aimed to raise awareness and mobilize action to prevent violence against women.

### 2008

In 2008, the UN launched the "Unite for a Better Tomorrow" campaign, which aimed to promote women's empowerment and gender equality.

### 2009

In 2009, the UN launched the "Women and Men United to End Violence against Women and Girls" campaign.

### 2010

In 2010, the UN launched the "Equal Rights, Equal Opportunities" campaign, which aimed to promote women's empowerment and gender equality.

### 2011

In 2011, the UN launched the "100 Years of International Women's Day" campaign, which aimed to celebrate the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day.

### 2012

In 2012, the UN launched the "Empower Rural Women, End Hunger and Poverty" campaign.

### 2013

In 2013, the UN launched the "A Promise is a Promise: Time for Action to End Violence against Women" campaign.

### 2014

In 2014, the UN launched the "Equality for Women is Progress for All" campaign.

### 2015

In 2015, the UN launched the "Empowering Women, Empowering Humanity: Picture It!" campaign.

### 2016

In 2016, the UN launched the "Planet 50-50 by 2030: Step It Up for Gender Equality" campaign.

### 2017

In 2017, the UN launched the "Women in the Changing World of Work: Planet 50-50 by 2030" campaign.

### 2018

In 2018, the UN launched the "Time is Now: Rural and Urban Activists Transforming Women's Lives" campaign.

### 2019

In 2019, the UN launched the "Think Equal, Build Smart, Innovate for Change" campaign.

### 2020

In 2020, the UN launched the "I am Generation Equality: Realizing Women's Rights" campaign.

### 2021

In 2021, the UN launched the "Women in Leadership: Achieving an Equal Future in a COVID-19 World" campaign.

### 2022

In 2022, the UN launched the "Gender Equality Today for a Sustainable Tomorrow" campaign.

### 2023

In 2023, the UN launched the "DigitALL: Innovation and technology for gender equality" campaign.

### 2024

The UN theme for International Women's Day in 2024 will be announced in the coming months.

Around the world
-----------------

International Women's Day is celebrated in different ways around the world. In some countries, it is a public holiday, while in others, it is marked with events and rallies. In some countries, women are given gifts and flowers, while in others, men take on domestic chores for the day.

Official United Nations themes
-----------------------------

Each year, the United Nations selects an official theme for International Women's Day. The themes are designed to promote women's empowerment and gender equality.

See also
--------

### Other holidays honoring women and girls

* International Day of the Girl Child (October 11)
* International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women (November 25)
* International Women's Year (1975)

Notes
-----

This article is a general overview of International Women's Day. For more information, please see the references and further reading sections.

The 2022–23 I-League 2nd Division is the 15th season of the I-League 2nd Division, the third tier of Indian football league system. The season will feature a total of 20 teams, divided into four groups of five teams each.

#Changes from last season

The previous season was played in a bio-secure bubble due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, this season will be played in a home-and-away format, with teams playing each other twice. The top team from each group will qualify for the final round, along with the best second-placed team.

#Qualification

##Selection criteria

The qualification process for the I-League 2nd Division involves a combination of state league performances, reserve teams, and a qualification tournament. The All India Football Federation (AIFF) has set certain criteria for teams to participate in the league.

##Reserve teams

##Qualification tournament

article:
2023 Giro d'Italia

The 2023 Giro d'Italia was the 106th edition of the Giro d'Italia, one of cycling's three Grand Tours. The race started on May 6, 2023, in Fossacesia, Italy, and concluded on May 28, 2023, in Rome, Italy. The race was won by Primož Roglič of Team Jumbo-Visma, who claimed his first Giro d'Italia title.

# Teams

The 2023 Giro d'Italia featured 22 teams, each with 8 riders, for a total of 176 riders. The teams were:

* AG2R Citroën Team
* Astana Qazaqstan Team
* Bahrain - Victorious
* Bora - Hansgrohe
* Cofidis
* EF Education - EasyPost
* Groupama - FDJ
* Ineos Grenadiers
* Intermarché - Circus - Wanty
* Israel - Premier Tech
* Jumbo-Visma
* Movistar Team
* Quick-Step Alpha Vinyl Team
* Team BikeExchange - Jayco
* Team DSM
* Team TotalEnergies
* Trek - Segafredo
* UAE Team Emirates

# Pre-race favourites

The pre-race favourites for the 2023 Giro d'Italia included Primož Roglič, who was seeking his first Giro title, and Geraint Thomas, who was looking to add to his Grand Tour collection. Other favourites included João Almeida, Richard Carapaz, and Jai Hindley, who were all seeking to improve on their previous Giro performances.

# Route and stages

The 2023 Giro d'Italia route covered a total distance of 3,489.2 kilometres, with 21 stages, including two time trials and seven mountain stages. The route took the riders through the Italian regions of Abruzzo, Lazio, Campania, and Tuscany, before concluding in Rome.

The stages were:

* Stage 1: Fossacesia to Ortona (203 km)
* Stage 2: Teramo to San Salvo (202 km)
* Stage 3: Vasto to Melfi (216 km)
* Stage 4: Venosa to Lago Laceno (175 km)
* Stage 5: Atripalda to Salerno (171 km)
* Stage 6: Naples to Naples (162 km)
* Stage 7: Capua to Gran Sasso (218 km)
* Stage 8: Terni to Fossombrone (194 km)
* Stage 9: Savignano sul Rubicone to Cesena (35 km, ITT)
* Stage 10: Scandiano to Viareggio (196 km)
* Stage 11: Camaiore to Tortona (219 km)
* Stage 12: Bra to Rivoli (185 km)
* Stage 13: Borgofranco d'Ivrea to Crissolo (152 km)
* Stage 14: Sierre to Cassano Magnago (194 km)
* Stage 15: Seregno to Bergamo (195 km)
* Stage 16: Sabbio Chiese to Monte Bondone (202 km)
* Stage 17: Pergine Valsugana to Caorle (197 km)
* Stage 18: Oderzo to Val di Zoldo (161 km)
* Stage 19: Longarone to Tre Cime di Lavaredo (183 km)
* Stage 20: Tarvisio to Monte Lussari (18 km, ITT)
* Stage 21: Rome to Rome (126 km)

# Classification leadership

The classification leaders were:

* General classification: Primož Roglič
* Points classification: Jonathan Milan
* Mountains classification: Thibaut Pinot
* Young rider classification: João Almeida
* Team classification: Team Bahrain - Victorious

## General classification

The final general classification was:

1. Primož Roglič (Team Jumbo-Visma) - 85h 29' 02"
2. Geraint Thomas (Ineos Grenadiers) - +14"
3. João Almeida (UAE Team Emirates) - +1' 15"

# Notes

The 2023 Giro d'Italia was notable for being one of the closest Grand Tours in recent history, with the top three riders separated by just over a minute.

2022 Kwibuka Women's T20 Tournament

The 2022 Kwibuka Women's T20 Tournament was a women's Twenty20 International (T20I) cricket tournament held in Rwanda from June 9 to June 18, 2022. The tournament featured eight teams: Botswana, Brazil, Germany, Kenya, Namibia, Nigeria, Rwanda, and Tanzania. The event was part of a series of tournaments organized by the International Cricket Council (ICC) to promote women's cricket globally.

# Squads

Each team played with a squad of 15 players. The squads for the participating teams were as follows:

article:
The Flash (film)
================

The Flash is an upcoming American superhero film based on the DC Comics character of the same name. The film is a part of the DC Extended Universe (DCEU) and is scheduled for release in 2022. Directed by Andy Muschietti and written by Christina Hodson, the film stars Ezra Miller as the titular character, alongside Michael Keaton, Ben Affleck, and Sasha Calle.

Plot
-----

The Flash follows the story of Barry Allen, a crime scene investigator who gains the ability to move at superhuman speeds after being struck by lightning. As he tries to navigate his new powers, he becomes the Fastest Man Alive, using his abilities to fight crime and protect Central City.

The film's plot is expected to explore the concept of the multiverse, with Barry Allen meeting different versions of himself and other DC characters from different universes. The story will also delve into the character's emotional journey, as he struggles to balance his personal life with his responsibilities as a superhero.

Cast
-----

* Ezra Miller as Barry Allen / The Flash
* Michael Keaton as Bruce Wayne / Batman (Earth-89)
* Ben Affleck as Bruce Wayne / Batman (DC Extended Universe)
* Sasha Calle as Supergirl
* Kiersey Clemons as Iris West
* Maribel Verdú as Nora Allen
* Ron Livingston as Henry Allen

Production
------------

### Development

#### Early attempts

The Flash film has been in development since the early 2000s, with several different scripts and directors attached to the project over the years. In 2004, Warner Bros. announced plans to produce a Flash film, with Shawn Levy set to direct and Ryan Reynolds attached to star. However, the project stalled, and Reynolds went on to play the role of Green Lantern in the 2011 film of the same name.

In 2013, Warner Bros. announced plans to reboot the DC Comics film universe, with a new Flash film in development. The project was initially set to be written by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller, with Ezra Miller attached to star. However, the duo left the project in 2016, citing creative differences.

#### DC Extended Universe

In 2013, Warner Bros. announced plans to create a shared universe for their DC Comics characters, with the Flash film set to be a part of the DC Extended Universe (DCEU). The film was initially set to be released in 2018, but was later pushed back to 2022.

### Pre-production

In 2016, Warner Bros. announced that Andy Muschietti would direct the film, with Christina Hodson set to write the script. The duo had previously worked together on the 2017 film "It".

In 2019, the film's cast was announced, with Ezra Miller set to reprise his role as Barry Allen. Michael Keaton and Ben Affleck were also announced to be joining the cast, with Keaton set to play an older version of Batman from the 1989 film universe.

### Filming

Principal photography for the film began in April 2021, with filming taking place in the United Kingdom. The film's production was initially set to last for six months, but was later extended due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

### Post-production

Post-production for the film began in October 2021, with the film's visual effects and editing being completed. The film's score was composed by Benjamin Wallfisch, who had previously worked on the scores for the 2017 and 2019 "It" films.

Music
------

The film's score was composed by Benjamin Wallfisch, with the soundtrack set to be released in 2022. The score features a mix of orchestral and electronic elements, with the composer incorporating themes from previous DC Comics films.

Marketing
---------

The film's marketing campaign began in 2020, with the release of a teaser trailer at the DC FanDome event. The trailer featured footage of Ezra Miller as Barry Allen, as well as Michael Keaton and Ben Affleck as Batman.

In 2022, the film's official trailer was released, featuring footage of the film's action sequences and emotional moments. The trailer also featured a glimpse of Sasha Calle as Supergirl, with the character set to make her DCEU debut in the film.

Release
-------

### Theatrical

The Flash is set to be released in theaters on June 23, 2022, in the United States. The film will be released in IMAX and 3D formats, with select theaters set to show the film in Dolby Cinema.

### Home media

The film will be released on home media in the fall of 2022, with the DVD and Blu-ray set to feature deleted scenes and behind-the-scenes footage. The film will also be available to stream on HBO Max.

Reception
----------

### Box office

The Flash is expected to perform well at the box office, with the film set to gross over $1 billion worldwide. The film's opening weekend is expected to be one of the biggest of the year, with the film set to open in over 4,000 theaters in the United States.

### Critical response

The film has received positive reviews from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences and emotional moments. The film's visual effects have also been praised, with the film's use of the multiverse concept being seen as a highlight.

### Accolades

The film has been nominated for several awards, including the Academy Award for Best Visual Effects. The film's score has also been nominated for several awards, including the Grammy Award for Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media.

Future
------

The Flash is set to be followed by several spin-off films, including a solo film for Sasha Calle's Supergirl character. The film's success is also expected to lead to a new wave of DC Comics films, with Warner Bros. set to announce several new projects in the coming months.

article:
First Period Houses in Massachusetts (1660–1679)

The First Period of American architecture refers to the earliest styles of building in the United States, specifically the colonial era from the early 17th century to the late 18th century. In Massachusetts, this period saw the construction of many houses that still stand today, showcasing the architectural styles and techniques of the time. This article will explore the First Period houses in Massachusetts, specifically those built between 1660 and 1679.

#Legend

Before delving into the specifics of First Period houses in Massachusetts, it is essential to understand the terminology used to describe these structures. The "First Period" refers to the earliest phase of American architecture, roughly spanning from 1600 to 1700. Within this period, several sub-styles emerged, including the Post-Medieval English, Early Colonial, and Medieval styles. These styles were characterized by the use of local materials, such as wood and stone, and the influence of English and European architectural traditions.

#1660–1670

During the 1660s, Massachusetts saw a significant increase in population and economic growth, leading to an expansion of building activity. Many of the houses constructed during this period were built using traditional English methods, with modifications to suit the local climate and available materials.

##Post-Medieval English Style

The Post-Medieval English style was a dominant force in Massachusetts architecture during the 1660s. Characterized by the use of wood framing, steeply pitched roofs, and central chimneys, this style was well-suited to the local climate. Many examples of Post-Medieval English houses from this period still stand in Massachusetts, including the Fairbanks House (1636) in Dedham and the Parson Capen House (1683) in Topsfield.

##Early Colonial Style

The Early Colonial style emerged in the 1660s as a distinct variation of the Post-Medieval English style. Characterized by the use of clapboard siding, central chimneys, and a more symmetrical facade, this style was popularized by wealthier colonists. The John Whipple House (1650) in Ipswich is an excellent example of an Early Colonial-style house from this period.

##Medieval Style

The Medieval style, also known as the "saltbox" style, was a popular choice for Massachusetts colonists during the 1660s. Characterized by a long, sloping roofline and a central chimney, this style was well-suited to the local climate and available materials. The Thomas Lee House (1660) in East Lyme, Connecticut, is an excellent example of a Medieval-style house from this period.

#1671–1679

The late 1670s saw a continuation of the architectural trends established in the 1660s, with a growing emphasis on ornamentation and decorative details. Many of the houses constructed during this period featured elaborate door surrounds, carved woodwork, and other decorative elements.

##Ornate Door Surrounds

One of the defining features of Massachusetts houses from the late 1670s is the ornate door surround. Characterized by intricate carvings, moldings, and other decorative elements, these door surrounds added a touch of elegance to the facade of the house. The Samuel Fowler House (1674) in Danvers is an excellent example of a house from this period featuring an ornate door surround.

##Carved Woodwork

The late 1670s also saw a growing emphasis on carved woodwork in Massachusetts houses. Characterized by intricate carvings, moldings, and other decorative elements, this type of woodwork added a touch of elegance to the interior of the house. The Gedney House (1665) in Salem is an excellent example of a house from this period featuring carved woodwork.

##Other Decorative Elements

In addition to ornate door surrounds and carved woodwork, many Massachusetts houses from the late 1670s featured other decorative elements, such as wainscoting, paneling, and ornate chimneypieces. The John Howland House (1667) in Plymouth is an excellent example of a house from this period featuring a range of decorative elements.

#See also

* First Period architecture
* Colonial Revival architecture
* Post-Medieval English architecture
* Early Colonial architecture
* Medieval architecture
* Saltbox architecture

#Notes

This article is a general overview of First Period houses in Massachusetts, specifically those built between 1660 and 1679. While every effort has been made to provide accurate and comprehensive information, there may be omissions or errors. Readers are encouraged to consult additional sources for more detailed information on this topic.

article:
BTS

BTS, also known as the Bangtan Boys, is a South Korean boy band formed by Big Hit Entertainment in 2013. The group consists of seven members: RM, Jin, Suga, J-Hope, Jimin, V, and Jungkook. Known for their energetic live performances, thought-provoking lyrics, and diverse musical styles, BTS has become a global phenomenon, breaking cultural and linguistic barriers and inspiring a devoted fan base.

# Name

The name "BTS" stands for the Korean phrase "" (Bangtan Sonyeondan), which translates to "Bulletproof Boy Scouts" in English. The name represents the group's desire to protect their fans from the harsh realities of the world and to be a source of comfort and inspiration.

# History

## 2010–2014: Formation and early years

BTS was formed in 2010 by Big Hit Entertainment's founder, Bang Si-hyuk. The group's original lineup consisted of RM, Jin, Suga, J-Hope, Jimin, V, and Jungkook, who were all selected through auditions. The members trained for three years, honing their skills in singing, rapping, and dancing.

## 2014–2017

### Skool Luv Affair and first concert tour

BTS made their debut on June 13, 2013, with the single "No More Dream" from their debut album "2 Cool 4 Skool". The group's early work was influenced by hip-hop and R&B, with lyrics that focused on themes of youth and rebellion. In 2014, BTS released their second EP "Skool Luv Affair", which included the hit single "Boy In Luv". The group's first concert tour, "2014 BTS Live Trilogy Episode II: The Red Bullet", took place in October 2014.

### Mainstream breakthrough and commercial success

BTS's breakthrough came in 2015 with the release of their third EP "The Most Beautiful Moment in Life, Part 1", which included the hit single "I Need U". The group's music began to appeal to a wider audience, and they started to gain mainstream recognition. In 2016, BTS released their second studio album "Wings", which debuted at number 26 on the US Billboard 200 chart.

### You Never Walk Alone and Love Yourself: Her

In 2017, BTS released the repackage album "You Never Walk Alone", which included the hit single "Spring Day". The group also released their first Japanese studio album "BTS World Tour: Love Yourself: Her", which debuted at number one on the Japanese Oricon Albums Chart.

## 2018–2020

### Love Yourself album series

In 2018, BTS released the album "Love Yourself: Tear", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart. The album included the hit single "Fake Love". The group also released the album "Love Yourself: Answer", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart and included the hit single "Idol".

### Map of the Soul: Persona, stadium world tour and BTS World

In 2019, BTS released the album "Map of the Soul: Persona", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart. The album included the hit single "Boy With Luv", featuring Halsey. The group also embarked on their stadium world tour "BTS World Tour Love Yourself: Speak Yourself", which broke multiple records for ticket sales and attendance. In June 2019, BTS released the mobile game "BTS World", which became one of the most downloaded games in the world.

### Map of the Soul: 7, "Dynamite" and Be

In 2020, BTS released the album "Map of the Soul: 7", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart. The album included the hit single "On". The group also released the single "Dynamite", which became their first number one single on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart. In November 2020, BTS released the album "Be", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart.

## 2021–present

### "Butter", "Permission to Dance" and Proof

In 2021, BTS released the single "Butter", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart. The group also released the single "Permission to Dance", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart. In June 2022, BTS released the anthology album "Proof", which debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart.

### Military service and contract renewal

In June 2022, BTS announced that they would be taking a hiatus to focus on their individual solo projects. The members also announced that they would be enlisting in the military, with Jin being the first to start his service. In July 2022, BTS renewed their contract with Big Hit Music for another seven years.

# Artistry

## Influences

BTS's music is influenced by a wide range of genres, including hip-hop, rock, pop, and R&B. The group's members have cited artists such as Kendrick Lamar, Drake, and The Beatles as influences. BTS's lyrics often focus on themes of youth, rebellion, and self-empowerment.

## Musical style

BTS's music style is diverse and eclectic, incorporating elements of hip-hop, rock, pop, and R&B. The group's early work was influenced by hip-hop and R&B, with lyrics that focused on themes of youth and rebellion. In recent years, BTS has experimented with a wide range of musical styles, incorporating elements of rock, pop, and classical music into their sound.

## Lyrical themes

BTS's lyrics often focus on themes of youth, rebellion, and self-empowerment. The group's music often addresses issues such as mental health, social inequality, and self-acceptance. BTS's lyrics are often introspective and personal, with the members drawing on their own experiences and emotions to create authentic and relatable music.

# Impact

## Diplomacy

BTS has been recognized for their contribution to Korean culture and diplomacy. In 2018, the group was appointed as ambassadors for Korean tourism by the Korean government. BTS has also performed at numerous international events, including the 2018 Winter Olympics and the 2020 United Nations General Assembly.

## Fandom

BTS's fan base, known as the "ARMY", is one of the most dedicated and passionate fan bases in the world. The ARMY has been recognized for their charitable work and activism, with fans raising millions of dollars for various causes and organizations.

# Other ventures

## Endorsements

BTS has endorsed numerous brands and products, including Coca-Cola, McDonald's, and Samsung. The group has also partnered with fashion brands such as Gucci and Louis Vuitton.

## Philanthropy

BTS is known for their philanthropic work, with the group supporting numerous charitable causes and organizations. In 2018, BTS launched the "Love Myself" campaign, which raised millions of dollars for the Korean Red Cross and other charitable organizations.

# Accolades

BTS has won numerous awards and accolades, including multiple Melon Music Awards, Mnet Asian Music Awards, and Billboard Music Awards. The group has also broken multiple records for ticket sales and streaming.

# Members

* RM (Kim Nam-joon) - leader, main rapper, vocalist
* Jin (Kim Seok-jin) - vocalist, visual
* Suga (Min Yoon-gi) - rapper, producer
* J-Hope (Jung Ho-seok) - rapper, choreographer

2022 FIFA World Cup Final

The 2022 FIFA World Cup Final was the final match of the 22nd edition of the FIFA World Cup, a quadrennial international football tournament contested by the national teams of the member associations of FIFA. The match was played on December 18, 2022, at the Lusail Iconic Stadium in Lusail, Qatar.

#Background

The 2022 FIFA World Cup was the first edition of the tournament to be held in the Middle East and the Arab world. The tournament featured 32 national teams, including the host nation, Qatar, who automatically qualified for the tournament. The remaining 31 teams qualified through a series of qualifying matches, which took place between June 2019 and June 2022. The tournament was played between November 20 and December 18, 2022, with the final match being played on December 18.

#Venue

The Lusail Iconic Stadium was the venue for the 2022 FIFA World Cup Final. The stadium is located in Lusail, a city in Qatar, and has a seating capacity of 80,000 spectators. The stadium was designed by the British architectural firm, Foster + Partners, and was constructed specifically for the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

#Route to the final

##Argentina

Argentina qualified for the 2022 FIFA World Cup by finishing second in the CONMEBOL qualifying tournament. They were drawn into Group C, along with Saudi Arabia, Mexico, and Poland. Argentina won their group, defeating Saudi Arabia 2-1, Mexico 2-0, and Poland 2-0. In the round of 16, Argentina defeated Australia 2-1, and in the quarterfinals, they defeated the Netherlands 4-3 in a penalty shoot-out, after the match had ended 2-2 after extra time. In the semifinals, Argentina defeated Croatia 3-0, to reach the final.

##France

France qualified for the 2022 FIFA World Cup by winning the UEFA Group D qualifying tournament. They were drawn into Group D, along with Australia, Denmark, and Tunisia. France won their group, defeating Australia 4-1, Denmark 2-1, and Tunisia 1-0. In the round of 16, France defeated Poland 3-1, and in the quarterfinals, they defeated England 2-1. In the semifinals, France defeated Morocco 2-0, to reach the final.

#Pre-match

The pre-match buildup to the final was intense, with both teams confident of winning the tournament. The match was expected to be a closely contested encounter, with both teams possessing some of the best players in the world. The French team, led by coach Didier Deschamps, were looking to win their third World Cup title, while the Argentine team, led by coach Lionel Scaloni, were looking to win their third title as well.

#Match

##Summary

The match was played on December 18, 2022, at the Lusail Iconic Stadium in Lusail, Qatar. The match was attended by 88,966 spectators, and was refereed by Szymon Marciniak of Poland.

###First half

The match began with both teams creating scoring opportunities, but neither team was able to score in the first half. The French team dominated possession, but the Argentine team's defense was solid, and they were able to prevent the French team from scoring.

###Second half

In the second half, the match became more intense, with both teams creating scoring opportunities. In the 23rd minute of the second half, Lionel Messi scored the opening goal for Argentina, to give them a 1-0 lead. However, the French team equalized in the 36th minute of the second half, through a goal from Kylian Mbappé. The match ended 1-1 after 90 minutes, and the teams went into extra time.

###Extra time

In extra time, the French team took the lead in the 108th minute, through a goal from Kylian Mbappé, to give them a 2-1 lead. However, the Argentine team equalized in the 118th minute, through a goal from Lionel Messi, to send the match into a penalty shoot-out.

###Penalty shoot-out

In the penalty shoot-out, both teams scored their first three penalties, but the French team's fourth penalty was saved by the Argentine goalkeeper, Emiliano Martínez. The Argentine team then scored their fourth penalty, to win the match 4-2 in the penalty shoot-out.

##Details

#Post-match and legacy

The match was widely regarded as one of the greatest World Cup finals of all time, with both teams giving their all to win the match. The Argentine team's victory was their third World Cup title, and it marked a triumphant end to Lionel Messi's World Cup career. #History

##Stardust Planet

Stardust Planet is the predecessor to Star Planet and was established in the early 2000s. During its early years, the company focused on managing small-time idols and producing low-budget television shows. However, it wasn't until the mid-2000s that Stardust Planet started to gain recognition as a major player in the Japanese entertainment industry.

Stardust Planet was responsible for managing several idol groups, including Momoiro Clover Z, Shiritsu Ebisu Chugaku, and Sakura Gakuin. These groups achieved significant success and helped to establish Stardust Planet as a major force in the Japanese idol scene.

###Discography
